author: yahoo
title: Hi-Yo, Silver! Metals Stocks Are Not Done Going Up - TheStreet
text:
Reddit Email Print Reprint NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- Since the early 1970s, the public has been captivated by silver and for a good reason. In the '70s commodity boom, gold went from $100/oz to over $800 or an eight-fold increase. Silver on the other hand went from around $1.60/oz to an eye-popping $50/oz. You do the math.
Precious metals have been in a funk since late 2011 as global turmoil and tensions have failed to stir the bull, and inflation fears have been replaced with deflation realities.
In the past two months, gold and silver have seen new interest from investors with both the metal and the mining issues seeing higher lows and increasing volume to support the moves.

While we do believe that history tends to repeat itself--this is because human nature has not changed over the centuries--we don't look for silver prices to soar 30-fold. Right now we prefer gold over silver as buyers have returned to gold sooner, and we tend to favor the first mover.

In this first chart, above, we can see that the iShares Silver Trust (SLV) peaked in early 2011 and has been under selling pressure ever since. Also note the continuous decline in the On-Balance-Volume (OBV) line. Notice also how many times SLV failed to rally above the declining 40-week (200-day) moving average.

In this shorter-term chart of SLV, above, we can see more detail. Look at the OBV line at the bottom. Improvement started in September. Now compare that with the  SPDR Gold Trust ETF (GLD) chart below.

In this chart, above, take note how the OBV line on GLD started to turn up in late July, well before the movement on SLV. Silver bulls stay put. We have highlighted two names in recent weeks: Silver Wheaton   ( SLW - Get Report ) and Silver Standard Resources (SSRI).

SLW made a nice base around $12 and has made a strong move over the 50-day moving average. Notice how heavy the volume was at the lows. It's impressive! What does Ray Dalio know?

We wrote about SSRI just the other day as it was breaking out of a large rising (bullish) triangle.
Other junior names are on our watch list, and we will recommend them when appropriate.
